Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in assessing state protection availability, psychological assessments, and 'compelling reasons' under IRPA
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status due to threats in Mexico but did not seek adequate state protection
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to seek adequate state protection in Mexico
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to RPD decision
Assessment_Factor: Availability of state protection in country of origin
Application_Basis: Lack of state protection and subjective fear
Governing_Rule: Under IRPA, claimants must prove lack of state protection; 'compelling reasons' applies only if para. 108(1)(e) is invoked
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to rebut presumption of state protection
Harm_Assessment: Alleged risk of harm in Mexico due to threats
Cause_Description: Applicants claimed refugee status due to threats in Mexico but failed to seek adequate state protection
Evidence_Handling: Psychological reports not considered relevant to objective state protection analysis
Evidence_Issues: Psychological assessments not applicable to state protection determination
Evidence_Assessment: RPD assessed evidence of state protection and found it sufficient
Decision_Rationale: No evidence to rebut state protection presumption; 'compelling reasons' not triggered
Evidentiary_Issues: Irrelevance of psychological reports to state protection analysis
